title: MLB DFS Plays: Tuesday 9/24
text:
This article will outline the best daily fantasy MLB plays of the day at every position. We’ll take a comprehensive look across the DFS industry to uncover these core recommendations, factoring respective salaries into the analysis.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

We will be looking at the five-game main slate starting at 7:05 ET.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

PITCHER

Mike Clevinger - Cleveland (at Chicago White Sox)

There’s no shortage of quality arms on this slate, but Clevinger gets the nod in my opinion. His team is in must-win territory while holding a -270 moneyline designation against a White Sox team that ranks 19th in wRC+ with the fourth-highest strikeout rate in baseball (25.6%). Clevinger already stumped Chicago while tossing seven innings with two earned runs, two hits, and nine strikeouts on September 3. I’m considering that somewhere near his baseline tonight.

Also Consider: Gerrit Cole, Jack Flaherty, Noah Syndergaard

CATCHER / FIRST BASE

Mitch Moreland - Boston (at Texas)

Moreland checks in with a non-imposing salary, and you’ll need plenty of those if you decide to spend on pitching. Moreland will return to his old stomping grounds of hitter-friendly Globe Life Park to find an excellent matchup against Edison Volquez and bulk pitcher Ariel Jurado. The latter carries a vulnerable .363 wOBA split to left-handed bats, and Moreland is swinging a hot bat with four hits and three homers over his last three starts.

Also Consider: Yuli Gurriel, Carlos Santana

SECOND BASE

Brock Holt - Boston (at Texas)

Story continues

Holt makes for an intriguing bargain lift for all the same reasons outlined above with his teammate. While Holt doesn’t come close to Moreland in terms of power upside, he’s still a strong candidate for multiple hits and runs in a likely high-scoring game at Globe Life Park. There’s not much opportunity cost at second base tonight, so I’ll go ahead and lock in Holt for some much-needed value.

Also Consider: Cavan Biggio, Gavin Lux

THIRD BASE

Tommy Edman - St. Louis (at Arizona)

Edman is one of the hottest hitters on the planet right now, collecting 11 hits with two homers, two triples, and nine runs over his past six games. That includes multi-hit efforts in five of those contests. The high-contact tendencies of Arizona RHP Mike Leake should serve as fuel to Edman’s fire.

Also consider: Matt Chapman, Rafael Devers

SHORTSTOP

Amed Rosario - NY Mets (vs. Miami)

It’s hard to get a read on Miami RHP Sandy Alcantara, who is having a rollercoaster of a season. He looks out of sorts at the moment while allowing four earned runs in three of his past five starts. I wouldn’t be surprised if the Mets extended that tonight. Rosario is a sneaky-good candidate within that, as he’s swinging a confident bat with eight hits, three homers, nine RBIs, and one stolen base over his past seven outings. The Mets’ shortstop makes for a strong bargain at the position, which comes in handy if you don’t have the necessary funds for Carlos Correa, Marcus Semien, or Francisco Lindor.

Also Consider: Carlos Correa, Marcus Semien

OUTFIELD

Yasiel Puig - Cleveland (at Chicago White Sox)

You could realistically stack three Cleveland outfielders and call it good. The Indians will square off against the washed-up likes of White Sox LHP Hector Santiago and an uninspiring Chicago bullpen. Puig will enjoy the platoon advantage while swinging a hot bat with 12 hits over his past five games. Oscar Mercado and Franmil Reyes are set up perfectly in this matchup as well. Puig is my favorite, but all of them are on my shortlist through all DFS formats.

Ramon Laureano - Oakland (at LA Angels)

We can’t forget about Oakland tonight, who has a lefty-crushing lineup facing Angels’ southpaw Dillon Peters (.391 wOBA vs. RHB). Matt Chapman and Marcus Semien are great infield options, while Laureano represents the best option from the outfield. Speaking to that point, Laureano came off the disabled list several weeks ago, and it appears that he’s back on track with 10 hits, seven runs, six RBIs, and one steal over his past six starts. Don’t forget about Khris Davis and Mark Canha from the OAK outfield either.

Also consider: George Springer, Oscar Mercado, Franmil Reyes, Mark Canha, Michael Conforto, Khris Davis, Joc Pederson, JD Davis
